Layhout.heading: Adopt the Right Mindsets - Leverage
Layhout.text:
An effective engineer knows how to leverage his/her time to make every day a productive day.

Increase your leverage in daily activities

  • 1. Reducing the time it takes to complete a certain activity
  • 2. Increasing the output of a particular activity
  • 3. Shifting to higher-leverage activities

Direct energy toward leverage points, not just easy wins
"Can’t meet until tomorrow? How about 8am? Not free until afternoon? What about 1pm?" — Facebook hiring culture

Layhout.heading: Adopt the Right Mindsets - Optimize to Learn
Layhout.text:
Optimize for learning
"Think about... just 1% per day and build upon that every single day ... will make us 37x better, not 365% better" — Zappos CEO

Seeking work environments conducive to learning

  • What is the weekly or monthly growth rates of core business metrics (e.g., active users, annual recurring revenue, products sold, etc.)? Is it effective?
  • Are the particular initiatives that you’d be working on high priorities, with sufficient support and resources from the company to grow?
  • How aggressively has the company or team been hiring in the past year?
  • How quickly have the strongest team members grown into positions of leadership?

Categorize your work items to urgent & important, urgent & not important, not urgent & important, not urgent & not important. Find time to focus on "not urgent & important" items like personal development and maintaining relationship with your mentor

Fight procrastination
"If I only have 20 minutes before my next activity, then I will ..."

Layhout.heading: Execute, Execute, Execute - Move fast
Layhout.text:
Move fast to learn fast
The faster that you can iterate, the more that you can learn about what works and what doesn’t work
"If you never break anything, you’re probably not moving fast enough" — Facebook

Invest in time-saving tools
Shorten debugging and validation loops Master your programming environment
Prefer keyboard over the mouse. It took 12s to find a file, he switched files 60 times a day, thats 12 min navigating between files per day.
Don’t ignore your non-engineering bottlenecks

Layhout.heading: Execute, Execute, Execute - Metric
Layhout.text:
Measure what you want to improve Pick the right metric

  • Hours worked per week vs. productivity per week
  • Click-through vs. long click-through rates
  • Average response times vs. 95th or 99th percentile response times
  • Bugs fixed vs. bugs outstanding
  • Registered users vs. weekly growth rate
  • Weekly active users vs. weekly active the nth week

Valid your ideas early and often
Spend 10% effort to build a small informative prototype and validate

Layhout.heading: Execute, Execute, Execute - Estimation
Layhout.text:
Use Estimates<>Decompose project into granular tasks

  1. Estimate based on how long tasks will take, not on how long you or someone else wants them to take
  2. Probability distributions, not best-case
  3. Let the person doing the actual task make the estimate
  4. Beware of anchoring bias
  5. Use multiple approaches
  6. Beware of mythical man-mouth
  7. Validate against historical data
  8. Use timeboxing to constrain tasks that can grow in scope
  9. Allow others to challenge estimates
